sub_title: Product Consultant CCV Group (Compentence Centre Payment Acceptance)
summary:
About Ben:
Ben is employed at the CCV Group (Competence Centre Payment Acceptance), the terminal development group of CCV, and he started in september 2000. In his profession as Product Consultant he is a bridge between technology and commerce, able to explain complex technology or systems in simple words. Ben has a strong analytic ability, is always reasoning from customer perspective, Ben is always focussing on solutions and willing to help other people.
Based on his experience Ben has been the architect of a number of CCV Products like CCV P-Gateway and CCV Motion, and the CCV cloud solution vallen CCC (Ccv Cloud Connect) by writing clear Functional Designs which are worked out within CCV Group and are successful products in the CCV Product Portfolio.

About CCV:
CCV is an international organisation specialising in electronic payments in the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg and Germany. In Europe CCV ranks among the major providers of payment terminals. CCV further specialises in processing transactions and developing loyalty and customer card systems. Since 2007 CCV has been acting as a payment facilitator in accordance with Currence certification. In 2011 CCV became an official payment institution under the supervision of the Dutch Central Bank. With more than 137,000 customers and over 180.000 terminals in the Dutch market and over 500.000 terminals in Europe, CCV has built up a strong market position, providing both standard products and customised solutions. The head office of the company, founded in 1958, is located in Arnhem.

projects.title: Cloud Accessible Terminal (CAT)
projects.description:
In 2017 I became one of the founding fathers of the Cloud Accessible Terminal (CAT). Untill then communication protocols between Point Of Sale (POS) and Payment Terminals were always using LAN. These protocols could not be transported over public internet without extra measures, because of lack of encryption and authentication.
The CAT combines the on-line and off-line world and is the first CCV terminal that enables EFT transactions initiated in the cloud (website) and processed on the regular PINpad (Vx820) without extra measures in a full secure way. The CAT is provided as a PSP service. In stead of starting a iDEAL, PayPal, Mastercard or Visa transaction from the website, the website starts the transaction towards the PINPad directly using the same interface.
Pilots for kiosks (semi-unattended) start in Q3 2017. A solution for a full browser based attended POS devices is expected in 2018.

projects.title: CCV Motion
projects.description:
In July 2012 I became responsible to create the functional design of a product that was later called CCV Motion. For launching customer Q-Park we created a solution for the Off-street Parking Environment which gave the possibilty for users to drive in, drive out with debit or credit card. A PayStation (Pay on Foot) solution, Access Control to the Parking Garage and WebService made the solution complete. EMV, Tokenisation, No CVM (also for Debit cards) are the keywords within CCV Motion. CCV Motion is an online system, but also provides a solution when internet is unavailable (stand-in) or a card reader is out of order (manual procedure to book transactions) by storing transactions locally and evacuating the transactions later by usage of the WebService without storage of any PCI DSS sensitive data. 
By putting CCV EMV-terminals (with SRED and Open Protocols certificate) into the Entry gate Exit gate, PayStation and Door Reader and usage of CardTokens generated by these terminals, the entire parking environment (Gates, PayStations, DoorReaders, PMS and network) is out of scope for PCI DSS. 
The TOP 5 key players in Parking Management Systems in Europe have implemented or are busy implementing CCV Motion. Currently CCV Motion is up and running in the Netherlands, Belgium, Ireland, Germany and United Kingdom. Other European countries are expected to follow soon. 
Currently the CCV Motion is extended with contactless NFC payments (PayPass, PayWave).

projects.title: P-Gateway
projects.description: In June 2010 I became responsible for the functional design of the CCV P-Gateway. The CCV P-Gateway was created for the Off-street Parking Environment to move from offline magstripe payments to online authorisation and capturing of magstripe payments. The P-Gateway is based on one or more (central) payment terminals in the parking garage and give the Parking Management System the possibilty to do a online check at parking entry and a payment at parking exit and is easy to tune simply by adding (central) payment terminals connected to PMS. Readers in Entry and Exit gates and the interface towards their PMS was not affected with this solution, Readers, PMS and the network are still in scope of PCI DSS.

projects.title: CCV Pos Unatteded Petrol
projects.description: In May 2007 I was instructed to create a payment solution for Unattended Petrol Market. Based on OPI and IFSF EPS Server I created an OPI-design for CCV Pos able to support unattended fuel payments  using the deferred sale transaction type of the C-TAP protocol. This solution is used in the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxemburg.
